Body:
BC-PHOTO-BUDGET-NYT 
   ATTENTION EDITORS: The following photos are part of tonight's
New York Times Photo Package, moving Monday, 12/13/99. Photo
clients will automatically receive these photos via AP's
PhotoExpress or may download them from either the Wieck Photo
Database in Dallas at 972-392-0888 or from NYTPhotos on Newscom at
305-448-8411. Non-clients can make individual purchases by calling
(888) 603-1036 or 212-556-4204.

   (NYT31) NEW YORK -- Dec. 13, 1999 -- GUATEMALAN-RELIC-B&W --
Officials think this 2,000-year-old Mayan stone carving, found in a
Brooklyn garage, was stolen from a ruin. The relic, discovered last
month, will soon be shipped back to Guatemala, the Guatemalan
consul general in New York said Monday. (Frances Roberts/The New
York Times)

   (NYT30) OAKLAND, Calif. -- Dec. 13, 1999 -- FDA-BIOTECH --
Supporters and opponents of the use of gene-altered food protesting
Monday in Oakland. The conflicting protests, which co-existed
peacefully outside the federal building here, reflect the
increasing public concern about such crops, which have swept
largely unnoticed into American agriculture over the last decade.
(Peter DaSilva/The New York Times)

   (NYT29) ORINDA, Calif. -- Dec. 13, 1999 -- WALLSTREET-PAYDAYS --
Mark Long, 32, left his banking job to join Intraware shortly
before the company went public. ``Today, bankers are just hired
guns,'' he says. If Intraware does well, Long stands to earn
considerably more than he did as a banker, thanks to stock options.
But that is only one reason he left. ``You get tired of sleeping 45
minutes a night to sell someone else's business,'' he says. (Peter
DaSilva/The New York Times)

   (NYT28) WASHINGTON -- Dec. 13, 1999 -- ALBRIGHT-BERGER --
Secretary of State Madeleine Albright, left, and National Security
Advisor Sandy Berger during interviews earlier this month. The end
of the Kosovo war was supposed to be a moment of glory for
Albright, who had argued passionately for the fight. But instead,
Berger has eclipsed her in the last six months, bringing his
physical proximity to the Oval Office and his personal relationship
with President Clinton to bear on every foreign policy issue,
administration officials and foreign policy experts say. (Paul
Hosefros/The New York Times)

   (NYT27) IN THE BAY OF BISCAY, France -- Dec. 13, 1999 --
TANKER-SINKING -- A broken Maltese-registered tanker, the Erika,
sank off northwestern France on Monday, pouring thousands of tons
of fuel oil into the ocean. A slick, 10 miles long and 4 miles
wide, is off the coast of Brest in the Bay of Biscay. A maritime
spokesman said weather conditions would determine the outcome.
(French Navy/The New York Times)

   (NYT26) NEW YORK -- Dec. 13, 1999 -- YANKEE-STADIUM -- George
Steinbrenner, the primary owner of the New York Yankees, arrives to
work at the stadium in this 1996 photo. For the last five years,
Steinbrenner has repeatedly promised that he will soon announce
where he wants the Yankees to play when the lease at Yankee Stadium
runs out in 2002. But as Steinbrenner weighs his options, much of
the rest of New York has come to the conclusion that he is really
down to only two: staying in the Bronx whether that is in a
renovated Yankee Stadium or in a new ballpark. (Vic Delucia/The New
York Times)

   (NYT25) NEW YORK -- Dec. 13, 1999 -- NY-TRANSIT-ASSESS -- ``Show
us the money,'' says Transport Workers Union President Willie
James, left, at a press conference in Manhattan on Monday. ``Put
more money on the table so we can resolve this.'' The union's
33,000 members are threatening to walk off the job at 12:01 a.m.
Wednesday unless they reach a deal with the Metropolitan
Transportation Authority for pay increases and other benefits.
(Frances Roberts/The New York Times)

   (NYT24) NEW YORK -- Dec. 13, 1999 -- KRAMER-FASHION-3 -- Barneys
New York recently opened a Co-op expansion at its Madison Aveune
store, which KramerHutchison all-out designed. Other surprises are
also in evidence: metal birdcages the firm designed for live
parakeets (acquiescing to management's wish for birds), and vintage
1950s hospital equipment used to showcase clothes. (Barbara
Alper/The New York Times)

   (NYT23) NEW YORK -- Dec. 13, 1999 -- KRAMER-FASHION-2 -- Robin
Kramer and Jeff Hutchinson's company, KramerHutchison, ``brands''
fashion companies through the kind of details shoppers might
believe they don't notice. The company created the feel at the
downtown boutique Jeffrey, designing fixtures, dressing rooms,
wrapping stations and procuring the stores' signature fountain,
left. ``They said be true to yourself,'' says Ms Kramer of the
freedom granted her company on the assignment. (The New York Times)
LITE

   (NYT22) NEW YORK -- Dec. 13, 1999 -- KRAMER-FASHION-1 -- Robin
Kramer and the architect Jeff Hutchinson in KramerHutchison's new
space in Chelsea. Ms. Kramer's job defies a career-guidebook kind
of definition, but in a broad sense she is in the business of
``branding'' fashion companies through the kind of details shoppers
might believe they don't notice. (Carol Halebian/The New York
Times)

   (NYT21) LITTLETON, Colo. -- Dec. 13, 1999 - COLO-SHOOTING --
Eric Harris, left, and Dylan Klebold appear on a video surveillance
tape in the cafeteria at Columbine High School in April on the day
of their shooting rampage where they shot and killed 12 students
and a teacher before turning guns on themselves. The video was made
available by the Jefferson County Sheriff's department on Monday
who played the contents of the surveillance tape as well as tapes
made by the two teenagers as they planned the shooting massacre.
(The New York Times) LITE

   (NYT20) EAST HAMPTON, N.Y. -- Dec. 13, 1999 - OBIT-HELLER-B&W --
Author Joseph Heller at his home in 1994. Heller, whose darkly
comic first novel, ``Catch-22,'' defined the paradox of the no-win
dilemma and added a phrase to the American lexicon, died of a heart
attack at his home. He was 76. (Vic Delucia/The New York Times)

   (NYT19) BOSTON -- Dec. 13, 1999 -- INTERVIEW-SILBER-BOS - John
Silber in his office at Boston University. The former president of
Boston University has not gone gently into that good night. At 73,
he remains all edge. Silber is still the bantam who slashes at
intellectual opposition the way Confederate General Nathan Bedford
Forrest savaged Union lines. (Tom Herde/The Boston Globe)

   (NYT18) BOSTON -- Dec. 13, 1999 -- SCI-MILK-BOS -- Dr. Daniel
Cramer, right, looks at DNA sequencing with Evelyn Li, left, a
research fellow, at Brigham and Women's Hospital. Cramer has
researched a potential link between milk and ovarian cancer and
infertility in a study involving 500 Massachusetts women and in
international comparisons of health statistics based on a country's
milk consumption. (Pam Berry/The Boston Globe)

   (NYT17) EAST HAMPTON, N.Y. -- Dec. 13, 1999 - OBIT-HELLER-2 --
Author Joseph Heller outside his home in 1994. Heller, whose darkly
comic first novel, ``Catch-22,'' defined the paradox of the no-win
dilemma and added a phrase to the American lexicon, died of a heart
attack at his home. He was 76. (Tom Herde/The Boston Globe) LITE

   (NYT16) NEW YORK -- Dec. 13, 1999 -- MEMORY-THEATER-REVIEW --
Elizabeth Ashley and Sam Trammell star in ``If Memory Serves.'' The
production is a spoof with serious pretensions about recovered
memory and our twin national penchants for celebrity and the public
washing of dirty laundry. (Sara Krulwich/The New York Times)

   (NYT15) NEW YORK -- Dec. 13, 1999 -- BAUM-THEATER-REVIEW -- Ron
Leibman, kneeling, and Christopher Evan Welch in ``Adam Baum and
the Jew Movie.'' Leibman's star turn as Sam Baum, a 1940s movie
mogul in denial of his Jewish identity, will remind many
theatergoers of his Tony-winning portrayal of Roy Cohn, the
right-wing lawyer in denial over his homosexual identity in Tony
Kushner's ``Angels in America.'' (Sara Krulwich/The New York Times)

   (NYT14) UNDATED -- Dec. 13, 1999 -- NY-LOUIMA-VOLPE -- Abner
Louima pauses while speaking to reporters on Monday. Justin Volpe,
the former New York City policeman convicted of brutalizing Louima
with a broomstick in his rectum, was sentenced to 30 years in
prison on Monday. Louima, asked the court for a sentence that would
``send a message.'' In the background at left is Rev. Al Sharpton,
a civil rights activist. (Angel Franco/The New York Times) LITE

   (NYT13) APACHE POINT, N.M. -- Dec. 13, 1999 --
SCI-SLOAN-SKY-SURVEY-2 --The 100-inch telescope of the Sloan
Digital Sky Survey has a boxlike structure to buffer it against the
wind. Using a technique akin to overlaying thousands of faint X-ray
images to create one sharp picture, astronomers have discovered
that typical galaxies may be twice as large and contain twice as
much mass as suggested by previous measurements. (Fermilab Visual
Media Services/The New York Times)

   (NYT12) UNDATED -- Dec. 13, 1999 -- SCI-GEORGE-WASHINGTON-B&W --
George Washington on his deathbed, in an 1850s lithograph by
Regnier and Lemercier. Washington's doctors said the cause was
``inflammatory quinsy,'' a severe infection of the throat, but to
this day controversy has surrounded his death. (The New York Times)

   (NYT11) KUKES, Albania -- Dec. 13, 1999 -- SCI-POLIO -- Albanian
refugee children being vaccinating against polio and measles in
April. Nearly 40 years after the United States abandoned Dr. Jonas
Salk's injectable polio vaccine in favor of an oral version, the
pendulum has swung the other way. Starting in 2000, the government
will administer a series of old-fashioned polio shots that will use
a stronger version of what is essentially the Salk vaccine. (Edward
Keating/The New York Times)

   (NYT10) JERUSALEM -- Dec. 13, 1999 -- MIDEAST-ISRAEL
--Protesters, many of them settlers from the Golan Heights,
demonstrate against withdrawal from the strategic area captured by
Israel from Syria in 1967, on Monday outside the Israeli
parliament. After hours of impassioned debate, and just two days
before talks begin in Washington, Israel's parliament narrowly
endorsed Prime Minister Ehud Barak's quest for a comprehensive
peace settlement with Syria. (Rina Castelnuovo/The New York Times)
LITE

   (NYT9) UNDATED -- Dec. 13, 1999 -- SCI-SLOAN-SKY-SURVEY -- This
spiral galaxy is one of hundreds of millions of celestial
structures the Sloan Digital Sky Survey will find. Using a
technique akin to overlaying thousands of faint X-ray images to
create one sharp picture, astronomers have discovered that typical
galaxies may be twice as large and contain twice as much mass as
suggested by previous measurements. (Fermilab Visual Media
Services/The New York Times) LITE

   (NYT8) HAMILTON, N.J. -- Dec. 13, 1999 --
SCI-PERSONAL-TRAINERS-2 -- Tom Ruggia, a trainer at Powerhouse
Fitness in Hamilton, offering instruction at a hybrid session
combining features of a group exercise class and personal training.
``Personal training is on the rise, and there's a correlation
between that increase and the growth of people working with
trainers in groups,'' says Maeve McCaffrey, spokeswoman for the
International Health, Racquet and Sportsclub Association, a trade
organization in Boston. (Laura Pedrick/The New York Times)

   (NYT7) HAMILTON, N.J. -- Dec. 13, 1999 --
SCI-PERSONAL-TRAINERS-1 -- Rick Ellis working one-on-one last week
with Bret Lukasik, a trainer at Powerhouse Fitness in Hamilton.
These days, personal training is often not so personal. Around the
country, growing numbers of trainers are offering the benefits of
one-on-one fitness to small groups of people who would prefer to
sweat together. (Laura Pedrick/The New York Times)

   (NYT6) UNDATED -- Dec. 13, 1999 - VAN-GOGH-MOMA -- The Museum of
Modern Art, which abruptly lost its only two van Gogh drawings last
year, once again has one in its collection. The museum's chairman,
Ronald Lauder, bought this unusually large and turbulent van Gogh
drawing of olive trees last week at Sotheby's in London. He paid
$8.5 million, a record price for a van Gogh drawing. (Sotheby's/The
New York Times)

   (NYT5) NEW YORK -- Dec. 13, 1999 - GEORGE-PROFILE - Author
Elizabeth George at the Waldorf Astoria during a reception for
authors and publishers. Death by decapitation on a farm in a quiet
Yorkshire village, the impaling of a playwright in an isolated
Scottish hotel, the kidnapping and drowning of the daughter of a
member of Parliament. Ms. George's intricately plotted mysteries
take her readers through the English countryside and a wide range
of professions and crimes. (Rebecca Cooney/The New York Times)

   (NYT4) UNDATED -- Dec. 13, 1999 - OBIT-HELLER -- The cover of
Joseph Heller's 1961 novel, ``Catch-22.'' Heller, whose darkly
comic first novel defined the paradox of the no-win dilemma and
added a phrase to the American lexicon, died of a heart attack at
his East Hampton home. He was 76. (The New York Times)

   (NYT3) HOUSTON -- Dec. 12, 1999 -- NEW-BREASTS-HNS -- Carrie
Wood, 41, left, and Kathy Park, 47, say reconstructive surgery
helped them get on with their lives after they were diagnosed with
breast cancer. Both women had double mastectomies, which were
followed by reconstructive surgery. ``When you have the mastectomy
and you come out looking close to what you looked like before, it
makes you very thankful that medical technology is what it is
today,'' says Ms. Park. (Steve Ueckert/The Houston Chronicle) LITE

   (NYT2) BELZONI, Miss.-- Dec. 12, 1999 -- BLACK-FARMERS-2-HNS --
Edmond Clark extinguishes a blazing module of cotton on his farm in
Belzoni, Miss. The module, valued at about $6,000, was one of two
Clark had scheduled for pickup that morning. It also was the second
in as many weeks intentionally set on fire. Clark speculated the
fire was set by a competitor. But, as a handful of people who lived
nearby looked on, a teen-ager who confessed to starting the fire
out of boredom. (Andrew Innerarity/The Houston Chronicle Photo)

   (NYT1) BELZONI, Miss.-- Dec. 12, 1999 -- BLACK-FARMERS-1-HNS --
Edmond Clark a field of cotton his farm in Mississippi. Clark says
he can count on one hand the number of black farmers still farming
around Belzoni. In his eyes, black farmers, including himself, in
rural Mississippi are systematically being forced into extinction.
Clark was denied a share of an April settlement black farmers
reached with the government. (Andrew Innerarity/The Houston
Chronicle Photo)

   The New York Times News Service
Text:

305-448-8411. Non-clients can make individual purchases by calling
(888) 603-1036 or 212-556-4204.

   (NYT1) BELZONI, Miss.-- Dec. 12, 1999 -- BLACK-FARMERS-1-HNS --
Edmond Clark a field of cotton his farm in Mississippi. Clark says
he can count on one hand the number of black farmers still farming
around Belzoni. In his eyes, black farmers, including himself, in
rural Mississippi are systematically being forced into extinction.
Clark was denied a share of an April settlement black farmers
reached with the government. (Andrew Innerarity/The Houston
Chronicle Photo)
